awd_titl_txt: NRI: Collaborative Research: Autonomous Quadrotors for 3D Modeling and Inspection of Outdoor Infrastructure
awd_abstract_narration:
This project develops technologies to collect visual and inertial data necessary for constructing, offline, high-accuracy 3D maps of the structure for civil and industrial infrastructure such as bridges, power plants, and refineries.  It also develops technologies for online processing including localization, path planning and obstacle avoidance. The project builds a system that employs quadrotors to assist their human co-workers in visual inspections of the outdoor infrastructure to enhance efficiency and effectiveness of such operations.  The research advances the current state of the art in key areas of sensing, estimation, and control necessary for enabling small-size quadrotors to assist humans in visual inspections. In addition to improving the reliability of the nation's infrastructure, the project benefits researchers, developers, educators, and end-users in robotics by developing open-source, modular algorithms for quadrotors. The project offers educational and community outreach activities aligned with local efforts and state-wide initiatives, and seeks to increase diversity and attract underrepresented groups to Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) via a partnership with local high schools. 

This research addresses the fundamental challenges stemming from sensing and processing limitations that prevent the use of low-cost, small-size quadrotors in visual-inspection tasks. It focuses on a four-step process, where initially a quadrotor is tele-operated at a safe distance from the structure of interest to collect visual and inertial data necessary for constructing, offline, high-accuracy 3D maps of the structure. These maps are then used, by the inspection engineer, to designate areas of interest. Lastly, the quadrotor employs its onboard sensors to precisely localize with respect to the structure and navigate along the inspection route, while collecting additional data for increasing the accuracy and improving the reliability of future inspections. A key innovation is making information available in multiple forms and levels of abstraction so as to meet the often-conflicting needs of offline (e.g., visualization of inspection areas and planning information-rich paths) and online (e.g., map-based localization and obstacle avoidance) uses. Also critical is an information-driven approach for making maximum use of the limited sensing and processing resources available to the quadrotor. Lastly, a key advantage of the proposed approach is that it provides the foundation for continual improvement in accuracy and efficiency after each inspection flight.

por.por_cntn:
This award supported research towards the 3D visual perception system of small, low-cost unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs), specifically quadrotors, for the inspection of infrastructure. The overarching goal, in collaboration with the University of Minnesota, was to advance the current state of the art in key areas of sensing, estimation, and control necessary for enabling small-size quadrotors to assist humans in visual inspections of civil and industrial infrastructure such as bridges, power plants, and refineries. The scope at Stevens Institute of Technology was twofold: (i) the development of algorithms for real-time, dense depth map estimation, and (ii) the creation of an offline 3D reconstruction approach for accurate modeling of the structures of interest. The former effort aims to compute depth maps onboard for obstacle avoidance and coarse 3D mapping. The latter effort includes the design of appropriate representations for detailed, global 3D maps of the scene without the burden of low latency.

Important outcomes under the real-time thrust include an optimized multi-threaded implementations of the most popular matching functions used in stereo matching, namely, the sum of absolute differences, normalized cross-correlation and the census transform, that has been released as open-source software library on GitHub. This software achieves unprecedented throughput on both the CPU and the GPU, and is able to compute depth maps from videos taken by two synchronized, calibrated cameras at high frame rates. An alternative approach that benefits from multiple frames, at the expense of a moderate lag, has also been developed together with a novel dataset comprising hundreds short video clips, each with a ground truth depth map. The dataset was derived from the raw data of the Tanks and Temples dataset, which was released by Intel. It covers a need that is not addressed by current multi-view stereo datasets, specifically the lack of a testbed for developing online 3D reconstruction algorithms, which must operate with low latency. A novel plane sweeping multi-view stereo reconstruction algorithm that is based on superpixels and does not require exhaustive photoconsistency computation was also presented with the dataset.

In parallel, research was carried out on offline global surface inference from multiple images employing a representation by a set of tetrahedra. The resulting approach is capable of extracting connected meshes from noisy point clouds based on global reasoning on tetrahedra generated by 3D Delaunay triangulation. The surface is inferred on the dual of the tetrahedral graph, in which edge capacities are set by a deep neural network considering the photoconsistency, visibility conflicts and properties of the triangles. This effort combines the strengths of geometric reasoning, by selecting a representation the resolution of which adapts to the local details of the surface, and data-driven, learning-based methods, for deciding whether a triangle corresponds to true surface or not.

Throughout the project, pre-college and undergraduate students were either directly involved in aspects of the above research, or more broadly engaged in STEM research. Software created during the project has been released to the research community via open-source repositories, while the findings were presented in tutorials at major computer vision conferences.

  • One of the input images of a narrow baseline video (left) and depth maps computed using plane sweeping stereo (middle) and the superpixel-based variant of plane sweeping (right). The superpixel-based algorithm is twice as fast because it does not require exhaustive photoconistency computatons.
